First off I better say up front that this is not meant as a troll, or
to start some sort of flame war about unit testing....  I'm really
looking for simple insight from people who have been where I am now,
links to articles on the web and so forth....

I like, the rest off you, have heard great things about unit testing.
 I believe a lot of it.  I want to start writing unit tests for my
code and in general improve my development practices.   So I downloaded
JUnit, and read through some articles and examples.

They are all too trivial.

I am struggling as to how I can write unit tests for "real code".   
Most of the examples I see are testing objects that are VERY general
(lists, or other simple container classes, a calculator, etc..).   
But my "real classes" are written for my "real application" and as
such there is an entire environment that is created as they work
together.  Testing the classes in isolation seems next to impossible.

Some people will be quick to jump in and say that this must be a
fundamental problem with my design.. my classes shouldn't be so
dependent on each other, or something similar.    In some (trivial)
cases it is possible to write stand alone classes, and they are
fairly easy to test in isolation.  But a complex application needs
all sorts of classes that bind trivial bits together... and these
classes must rely on the very classes that they are causing to work
together.

I find that it is these classes that are difficult to
compartmentalize where most of my bugs tend to show up anyway, but of
course not always.   How do you unit test such beasts?

So far in all my attempts to get started at this I find that the test
code itself becomes very complex - not as complex as my application,
but enough that the time I would end up writing and debugging the
test seems completely unreasonable.   I would love to have the
finished tests, but I simply can't see how I could justify writing
them, as it would more than double my design and coding development
time.

In the end I would almost end up with an "automated user", and of
course that is a tad extreme and prone to it's own sorts of errors
and assumptions.

I've told co-workers about what I have read about unit testing,
testing frameworks etc.  None of my co-workers do unit tests, and ll
of them have the same attitude.  Unit testing is too
complex/difficult to use when making real complete programs.

So I'm asking... Who else has been down this path?  How do I get past
this point?   Am I making sense or have I just gotten something
completely wrong? Or is this unit testing just a passing fad that is
really nothing more than a bunch of hype?
